												ANOMALY WARZONE EARTH is surprisingly entertaining, with great tutorials. Its a top down somewhat tower defense game... only in reverse. You lead a squad of vehicles that must take clear cut streets through enemy defenses, but you select the route and your caravan just keeps following the path you set for them. So imagine a train that cannot stop on a tracks with multiple paths. If something blocks your train track, you divert your train at the next intersection by going to a tactical route map and just clicking on the intersection to point their next direction to head in. Its really as easy as that. You don't control the vehicles so much as just point out the route to take. You do have a player character to control. There is a 'speed up / turbo' button to make the game go faster.Since you're going through a warzone, the enemy has turrets, and other defenses setup to slow you down. So this is like you play the part of a GPS and they'll do the fighting as they come upon enemies. You can buy more vehicles for your caravan, upgrade current vehicles (for the same price as buying them new) and assign their formations. Like do you select a less defensive more offensive vehicle to go first or do you select a more defensive less offensive vehicle? Another thing to consider is range of attack. The 'attack crawler' vehicle has a longer range, but it is considerably weaker than the 'defender APCs.' Eventually you'll get shielders that will provide a shield for the vehicles directly in front and in back of them in the caravan train. There are also tanks that you will unlock later. In all the game's player vehicles seem limited in diversity.As a commander, you have abilities that you collect. The first is to repair your vehicles in a radius of where it is used for a specific time as the train keeps rolling. Your player character isn't limited to staying with the caravan, he can go out and wander to find things. This is a very simple yet engaging. The only downside is the controls could be better. A lot of times my commander was accidentally walking all over the place when I wanted him to repair things. Just because you hit the abilities menu, then select the ability with the mouse. Well when you use the mouse it makes your player character walk. The other abilities are, smoke screens that will cover vehicles in a radius preventing some cannons from hitting them and then decoys that will attract larger cannons that would otherwise accurately hit your vehicles in a smoke screen. Finally, there is a bomb target to bluntly bomb enemies. It might seem cheap, but it is useful for wide beam cannons that keep streaming a draining vehicles.Eventually the challenge outweighs the fun just gets too much on even the normal difficulty. When you have limited resources, money and enemies keep getting more and more powerful, such as giving enemies a damage radius to every bullet and enemies that ressurect destroyed towers. Once one of your vehicles is destroyed, I find myself wanting restart from the last checkpoint, because I know that one vehicle down will make my train too weak to beat later levels.Each level seems healthy time wise and you get to select your level of difficulty. It is definitely worth a play. Good instructions, good voice work explaining everything in a simple manner.

												Interesting variety of tower defense genre. You're in control of "invading" units in pre-built maps. At the beginning of each stage, you select your squad based on money you have. Commander is equally important as your other units, so you must learn to use him wisely.Once you get familiar with game mechanics, you can finish this game with almost same unit formation every time on any difficulty, but nevertheless, game is addictive and very fun to play. I highly recommend playing in combination with steam achievements which adds interesting tasks to do during missions (which also makes the game more difficult).Overall, if you like tower defense games, you probably won't regret getting this game.

												At first when I found out it was a "Reverse Tower Defense" where you control the units, I thought it'd be just another spam units when you had the money sort of thing. But was I wrong! 												A pretty nice game idea, playing like a reverse tower defence game, where instead of setting up towers and fighting off waves of enemies, you're navigating a small force of tanks and other vehicles into an enemy territory.There's a lot of strategy involved here, as you must choose your routes carefully and to engage just enough towers at a time so not to get overwhelmed, whilst using abilities such as smoke screen and decoys to mislead enemy towers and protect your allies in the process. There are several different enemy towers, and each one can pose a serious threat if you don't approach it with good strategy. And in addition to encountering various tower setups, the game often throws other challenges your way too, such as needing to get across a bridge in the area before it gets destroyed, or having to evade powerful area artillery strikes from the enemy, and so on.The game is really fun if you like tactical gameplay, but it's also pretty relentless and hard, even on Casual difficulty. If you're looking for a casual, relaxing game, you won't find it here. But if you're seeking a challenge, you'll be right at home. Unfortunately the game's checkpoint system can sometimes work against you. If you happened to reach a chekpoint when you're low on ability supplies and your vehicles are in poor shape, you might find yourself unable to make progress past the next area, and returning back to the previous section becomes impossible after a checkpoint. These times could cause you having to restart the whole level from the beginning.In addition to the 14 campaign missions, you also get some bonus challenges (Baghdad Mayhem and Tokyo Raid) which you can try out, where you're given a series of tasks (not related to the story) in an area and you must complete them. Overall, the presentation is pretty good. Great visuals, adrenaline-pumping music, and nice voice acting. So if you don't mind some challenge, this game is worth getting.

												The premise behind Anomaly: Warzone Earth is that of reverse tower defense. Instead of setting up your defense towers in lanes and waiting for the enemy to attack, your job is to attack towers that have been set up by aliens through various campaign missions. While this may sound like it makes the tower  defense genre more interesting, and provides a much needed change in a fairly strict genre, the truth is, it does not. Graphically, it's serviceable. The developers did a decent job porting the game from mobile devices, even though there aren't that many options besides resolution. The artwork varies from creatively rendered post-apocalyptic cities around the world, to alien structures and weaponry. Voice acting is below average, but it isn't too bad. The British accent in particular sounds fake and over the top. As for the plot, it's your below average teenage action science fiction with very little substance and grossly lacking in twists. Overall,  Anomaly: Warzone Earth is predictable from beginning to end, if you can stomach finishing the game. From its presentation, to the mechanics, to the storyline, there isn't anything that rewards the player, or provides a sense of accomplishment and value. Playing the game feels more like an annoyance. It also suffers from a severe lack of depth and range. There are only four unit types, six enemy types, and only four commander abilities that can only be activated if you pick up their ability icons that are dropped on the map by supply planes. There is very little variation from mission to mission, and even though upgrading your units is an option, there is very little reason to do so, as you will need to get more units on the field instead. Having only one or two upgraded units go through the lanes is guaranteed suicide. Another very serious problem with Anomaly: Warzone Earth is the difficulty. Even at the easiest setting, there will be some more advanced campaign missions that are nearly impossible to beat unless you do exactly what the developers wanted you to by design. There is no choice to be made. Finishing those artificially difficult missions is not due to skill or through learned strategies, but by saving and repeating the same abilities you have been abusing of throughout the entire campaign. There is no strategy nor skill involved. You simply repeat the same steps over and over, for every mission. It doesn't really matter what enemies you are facing, or what the pointless mission objective is. The game gives you a false sense of decision making, and a false sense of strategy. It feels like all actions being done in-game are worthless and with no consequences. It's almost like the game plays itself. Only needing you to click a bit, instead of looking stupid as you poke your phone or your tablet, if you were playing on the game's original mobile platform. There are many other tower defense games that provide the player with actual choice of action and strategy. Anomaly: Warzone Earth does nothing to make the tower defense genre better. In fact, it makes it worse.Anomaly: Warzone Earth is mediocre.

												Great tower defense game, although it's actually a tower attack one: you command a squad that needs to reach its destination, having to destroy every treat in your path and using your special abilities to make sure the squad gets there in one piece. You choose what type of vehicles you want in your squad based on how much money you have, set up the route and you're ready to go. The squad follows the route, which is limited to the streets, while you - the commander - can move everywhere. If a vehicle from your squad gets destroyed, it's gone. Lose all of them and your mission fails. You can also add / remove vehicles to your squad at any point throughout the mission, but you need money to add them: removing a vehicle gives you some money back, depending on how damaged it is. If you die, you respawn in the same place after a few seconds. As you progress through the game, harder and smarter towers start appearing: some can inflict damage to your entire squad at the same time, some can restore destroyed towers by sucking energy out of you every time you use a special ability in their field of view, some can turn your squad against you... It's a really fun game, and also has a very interesting story.

If you're a fan of the Tower Defense genre and/or you would like to try something out of your regular zone, Warzone Earth is not only an outstanding, a brilliant example but also an example for how you should reimagine, adapt your mobile game for PC Market.Plus, it runs on GNU/Linux!

The player assumes the role of the commander of an armor battalion (referred to as "14th Platoon" in the story) sent to investigate anomalies that have occurred in the vicinity of the wreckage and gather information on what is happening in the affected areas, as the anomalies are interfering with radar and satellite imagery - and to neutralize any threats that may exist within the anomalies' field of influence.Players control a convoy of vehicles investigating anomalies around sections of a downed alien spacecraft, which are protected by various types of defensive towers that have to be destroyed. Players do not directly control the vehicles in the convoy, rather they set paths for the convoy to follow along city streets, while also dropping power-ups such as decoys or smoke-screens to aid the survival of the convoy. In addition, players can purchase and equip a number of different units with varying offensive and defensive attributes to make up the convoy. In the Windows, Mac, Linux and XBLA versions, players directly control a soldier on foot (dubbed the Commander) whom they use to pick up and drop the power-ups for the convoy. The iOS and Android versions omit the Commander in lieu of the player directly placing power using the touch-based interface. 												TLDR: Anomaly Warzone Earth is a “reverse tower defense” game where you control a convoy trying to get through the mazes of enemy tower placements in an urban setting. Mix up your unit loadout and upgrade your units on the fly as you run alongside them using “special powers.”According to the game’s opening cinematic, in the not too distant future a bunch of mysterious objects fall from the sky, and end up encasing themselves is massive domes that the military call anomalies. You play a military commander tasked with infiltrating the anomalies and eliminating the alien menace inside. The game’s single player campaign has 14 discrete levels, where you control not only the commander on the field, but the convoy of vehicles which you need to guide through the level. It’s your choice whether to avoid or engage the alien towers that are set up all over the maps by manipulating the routes they take, similar to switching train tracks on railroads. Generally you should choose to find and destroy them since you earn money with which to upgrade or purchase more units. You get access to about half a dozen different unit types by the end of the game but it’s likely that you’ll stick to your favorites and just upgrade rather than having a large group of weak units. The vehicles are autonomous, you don’t choose who they fire at, just which direction they take through the cities. The “skill” portion of the game is in how you use your special powers in the field. Your little commander unit doesn’t have guns of his own, but he can “cast spells” such as repair, smoke screen, or decoy that make all the difference when your convoy is under fire. By the last level, you’ll be a spell casting fiend, just firing off your skills left and right as you’re bombarded by an overwhelming number (and variety) of enemy towers. Pros:+The game’s story is engaging and frames each level so you don’t just have 14 maps to play, you’re actually advancing the story, exploring the anomalies and the aliens’ plans.+The variety of units you can use and enemy towers is surprisingly complex. Some of the enemy towers are a major pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ like the one that absorbs energy if you use a special power within its line of sight. Cons:-The game is quite difficult at times, despite the “casual” difficulty setting. I tried replaying the game recently after about a year, just to experience the story again… and I couldn’t finish it again. It was fun the first playthrough, but the replayability value of the game just isn’t that high. Overall, the game is enjoyable and challenging, and the download size is under a gigabyte so go ahead and give it a try. I ended up not playing the different game modes though, like survival and mayhem. I guess I was just burnt out by the end.

												A very refreshing take on the tower defense series. The graphics are really good, and the music is pretty driving as well. The voice acting is good as well, other than the HORRIBLE fake Japanese accents. How hard is it to find someone with an actual Japanese accent?Superficial stuff aside, the gameplay is really solid. It's a blast having to manage your team, forming a good balance between offense and defense, planning your route strategically, all while using your commander to jump into the fray to heal units or call in strikes without getting him killed. It's really a welcome layer of strategy on top of the (what I consider to be) tedious tower defense genre.What didn't work so much for me was how the game seems to demand perfection. Granted, that's pretty much the tower defense genre anyway, but I was hoping this game would take a step backwards in that regard. If you lose even one of your units, not only will you most likely not have the resources needed to replace it, but you will be facing a DRASTICALLY harder battle. Borderline impossible, on any difficulty other than casual.Unfortunately, that means you will be doomed to replay the same mission over and over until you find the perfect formula for success. I am not a fan of games that devolve that way, but I genuinely enjoyed this one. I didn't play any of the extra modes though, as I was mostly done with it by the time I replayed the final mission for the 2-dozenth time.My suggestion is to give a rating to the tower defense genre as a whole on a scale of 1-100 and add 20 points to it. If you like/love tower defense games, you will enjoy this. If you are meh about them, you will still probably enjoy this. If you have never found a tower defense game that you really liked, then only pick this up in a massive sale.

												I'm sure most of you guys are familiar with the term 'tower defense'. It's a game where you build and upgrade towers to defeat waves of enemies and, later on, bosses trying to destroy your [insert something random here like a base or village]. If you've seen one of them you've seen pretty much all of them. Not this one though. This one is different. It's a reverse-tower defense title, meaning you have to run with an actual character and guide your tanks across a city. Along the way alien towers spawn on the sides of the road and it's up to you to change your formation, help them out yourself with dropping small nukes and smoke bombs and create a safe path using a virtual map of the city. It's actually quite refreshing and I suggest to anyone who loves TD games (like I do) to buy and try.[Rating: 85/100]

												A tower offence game where you lead a small group of tanks them around a tower filled map. Unlike the mobile campaign, you actually get to run around as the commander, the main interactions you have are: 1)	Buying and upgrading tanks. The main choices being heavy armour, high firepower or support (like a shield tank). Upgrading is very simple with no branching upgrade paths. 2)	Choosing which way your tanks navigate around the map, to either avoid clusters of towers or to go after the currency to buy more tanks. 3)	Deploying power ups. These are plentiful and the main way of keeping your tanks alive, by repairing them, deploying smoke or decoys to divert the attention of the towers. Other than some poor voice acting, the game is well presented. It’s not the most in depth game, but it’s easy to get into repetitive (almost the opposite of Gratuitous Tank Battles, another take on tower offence). Overall the concept it interesting enough to just about last the length of the fairly short campaign.

												I got really excited when I frist heard about this "reverse tower defense" or "tower offense" game. I played the first few levels and then it took me YEARS between then and ever feeling motivated to play the game again. I finally did and finished it and to my surprise it's only a couple hours long. Even doing everything I wanted to (bonus missions, mission-specific achievements, etc.) did not add that much time.But I'm thankful for the short length, because I did not enjoy it.The game's concept is great, but the execution is not good. Despite the fact that the game keeps introducing new enemies and units right up through the last mission - which actually sucked because you never had the full system figured out until the very end - I found myself oscillating between two very undesirable points.The first was more common: most levels were so easy as to be boring, even on higher difficulties. The second was shear frustration: getting stuck. The checkpoint system is totally inconsistent, as in some levels it will repeatedly reward you the same check point an infinite number of times, so that you can just get it as many times as you want, even every 10 seconds. But in other levels you'll go 15 minutes of gameplay without one and then have to reload. Frustraing. Annoying. And because of the set paths and limited resources if you do get a checkpoint late in a hard level where you don't have much money or health or abilities it might actually be impossible to finish the level and you have to restart. Accepting that is a painful process, but in some cases it's the only way forward.So for such a short game with a cool concept I feel like I got disproportionately frustrated and annoyed.The icing on the cake is that the story and the dialogue are abysmal.

												Wow! This is a great game. And this time I really didn't know what to expect at all from the game when I bought it. I just found the artstyle so appealing. I thought this would be another modern RTS game, this time with really stylish graphics that I'd enjoy to look at but never really gonna like to play ... but man was I wrong ...At it's core Anomaly is a Tower Defense game. Only this time you're not playing the defending but the offending forces. So this time around you are playing a commander of a motorised squad that will attack the towers but can't be controlled directly by you. You can offcourse set the routes for your squad and you have some special abilities like repairing, laying smoke curtains to hide or placing decoys to protect your units and so on.The style of the graphics, the sound, the music, the voice overs event the menus ... everything is blended perfectly alltogether to give a pretty unique gameplay experience of a sort I personally haven't encountered before.This game sucks you right in from the first minute because of its very unique style and easy accessibility featuring perfect XBox 360 controller support. Even the story is nicely spread out through the campaign. On top of that it seems to feature a good portion of replayability by offering a ton of missions: First there is the story mode, then there are two campaigns based on locations from the story mode and after that you can still play on in some bonus missions with extra difficulty and slight twitches to the original gameplay mechanics.I liked very much what I've seen unti now and I can wholeheartedly recommend you to buy this game, exspecially when it's on sale. But I must say (and I don't say this often) this game is even worth it's full price. So go on and get it if you're in for some thrilling action strategy sort of game you haven't seen anywhere else before.@ngel

												Especially with the great sale going on right about now, I certainly recommend people buy this game. Now, I will grant that it isn't perfect: it's long-lasting value is questionable, it's plot/storyline is not necessarily flourishing with detail and impact (I think), and the voiceacting I simply can't help but smirk at. But, this game definitely gets great points from me for innovation, presenting a new take on strategy and an innovative application of the tried tower defense genre. As the game progresses—at least in my case—you get the feeling that you've totally got this, but new features, units, and adversaries are constantly added and you are constantly expected to rethink your tactics to combat a threat that becomes less and less predictable and linear. Anomaly starts out simple, but eventually your ability to strategize is truly put to the test as more complicated battlefields filled with convoluted arrays of kinetic and non-kinetic threats appear.On the practical side, this is a "tower attack" game (you play the role of a commander leading your squad of units through turret-infested landscapes), but with many innovative nuance, such as abilities that can buff your units or detriment your adversaries, the ability to purchase and upgrade your units to create a personalized squard as you move through the city blocks, and the opportunity to choose what path you want your units to take, giving you the choice of whether or not you want to try and score some bonus cash that is sitting in a swarm of defenders, or avoid combat as much as you can in order to survive through the finish. Missions are comprehensive and fun to play but are short enough that you can open this game just for a quick round, and its progressing difficulty and story keep it interesting from start to finish.Oh, and let's not forget that this game was produced by a Polish company, and anything coming out of Poland has to be good (absolutely no bias whatsoever in this final statement).

												A brilliant take on the reverse tower defense, this game is well worth its $10 price tag. The story keeps you engaged and halfway through you still dont know what the Anomaly is. It helps that the Commander (controlled by YOU) doesn't have any weapons to defend himself. Which prevents you from going Rambo and leaving your convoy behind. However you do get useful abilites that will help your men to reach safely to the end zone. All this means you stay close to your team and provide and direct support as a real team leader would.You aren't confined to a single path and can change your route midway through the game. Even as new obstacles pop up it's still in your hands whether you want to brave it and push through, or find an alternate route. However, a few levels do force you to take a certain path for small sections.The enemy towers while challenging haven't got much variety and you learn how to deal with them easily. However the real challenge comes in what direction you need to attack them from. What might seem like the easiest or the shortest path might also be the hardest.Overall a 7/10  Would be great if there were more special abilities or enemy tower types

												It's a tower defence game with a twist, which is that you are the convoy going against the towers. The gameplay is fairly simple and yet it retains enough compelling strategy to be worth playing. You basically have to plot a route that is most survivable, while gathering most resources. You have control over a commander, who can move anywhere on the battlefield and he is your only means of interaction, enabling you to boost the health of your convoy whilst dropping smoke and calling in air strikes. There are also vehicle upgrades to earn. The convoy appears to move slowly, but you are constantly being set goals and needing to take your eye off it in order to send your commander off on his own. Extra challenging elements are thrown in, such as airborn friendlies plotting their own course across the map.Graphically and sonically, the game is really quite impressive. Overall it isn't the most amazing game you'll ever play, but it succeeds in being fun and providing a good mix of strategic forward planning with realtime action. The main source of irritation I have found is that there is no save game feature; only a checkpoint system. There's no way to rewind back past the most recent checkpoint. Occasionally, the game surprises you with something you couldn't anticipate and you realise that your strategy up to that point won't enable you to finish the level, which means you have to start again from the very beginning.

The gameplay is fairly simple and yet it retains enough compelling strategy to be worth playing. You basically have to plot a route that is most survivable, while gathering most resources. You have control over a commander, who can move anywhere on the battlefield and he is your only means of interaction, enabling you to boost the health of your convoy whilst dropping smoke and calling in air strikes. There are also vehicle upgrades to earn. The convoy appears to move slowly, but you are constantly being set goals and needing to take your eye off it in order to send your commander off on his own. Extra challenging elements are thrown in, such as airborn friendlies plotting their own course across the map.Graphically and sonically, the game is really quite impressive. Overall it isn't the most amazing game you'll ever play, but it succeeds in being fun and providing a good mix of strategic forward planning with realtime action. The main source of irritation I have found is that there is no save game feature; only a checkpoint system. There's no way to rewind back past the most recent checkpoint. Occasionally, the game surprises you with something you couldn't anticipate and you realise that your strategy up to that point won't enable you to finish the level, which means you have to start again from the very beginning.

												To start, let me say that I love Tower Defense games. Orcs Must Die!, Sanctum, Dungeon Defenders, I love this genre because it's all about controling the flow of the enemy hordes; making them go in one direction versus another, leading them into a well armed trap and shooting them dead. While to some that may seem like it would kill replay value once you know the "optimal" placements, in most games it doesn't because there is always more than one effective way to work the map.This game takes Tower Defense and does a 180. You don't control the towers, the towers are the enemy. Instead of planning out how to lay traps, where to place key damage towers and how to funnel enemies towards the kill zone you're tasked with navagating a convoy through a map with multiple path options, strewn with enemy towers intent on killing you. Welcome to Tower Offense.Aside from the convoy's attack power (which you can upgrade with enough money, or replace lost units), you've got special powers that let you repair units, lay down a smoke screen, drop decoys and so one. Each uses a unique 'charge' so you'll be running all over the map going between using the abilites and picking up drops so you don't run out. Here the camera is what all TD players are used to; top-down isometric. But it's locked at a specific zoom level and can't be zoomed in (not sure why you'd want to, but it needed to be mentioned) and zooming out opens the tactical route map which lets you see where all currently visible enemy towers are on the map (some will pop up as part of the story and won't be visible until then) and plan your convoy's route, letting you change it on the fly in case something happens to block your current route.It's a fun game, and a break from the typical TD mindset without needing to add in in FPS elements like the Sanctum series (another fine series of games, BTW) or Orcs Must Die! (which has some RPG elements to it and in 3rd-Person). One key aspect of this game is that it can basically be played using just the mouse, because by default almost all commands are already assigned to Mouse 1, 2, 3 and the wheel (no shoulder buttons), so it's easy to pick up and play, but mastering what routes to take is where you'll spend a lot of time.

												The quick way to describe Anomaly is that it's a reverse tower defence game, but to me that sells it a bit short by comparison - there's a lot more to the gameplay than in most tower defence games. Along with the expected concept of managing a troop of units past some towers, you have a 'hero' unit free to roam around the map, collecting and deploying special abilities (mostly defensive to protect your units or distract foes, but you get an airstrike later on to attack enemy towers), which adds a nice layer of depth. Additionally, you have complete control over the path of your units through the towers - levels are often set in city areas with many possible routes to take. New elements are added at a fairly consistent rate, so each level feels distinct, which is also helped by some neat unique features in certain levels (for a few examples, in one level, enemies try to destroy bridges to block your path, in another you have to 'escort' your transport flying slowly through the level by clearing the towers in its path). The plot is a bit generic and the cutscenes sometimes feel like they get in the way of the gameplay, but it gives an excuse for an excellent setting and overall style, so it's forgivable.In short, Anomaly plays great and looks great, so if you want to flip the script and start knocking down some towers, give it a spin.
